Overview of Family Dependency Treatment Courts
Overview of Family Dependency
Treatment Courts

• What are they? • Why do we need them? • What are the unique
• What are they?

characteristics?
characteristics?

What is Family Dependency Treatment Court
What is Family Dependency
Treatment Court

Definition:
Definition:

A court that deals with cases involving children who have been abused or neglected by a parent or caregiver as a result of substance abuse and who are the subject of court proceedings that oversee social service efforts to rehabilitate families or to provide alternate permanent plans for children.
A court that deals with cases involving
children who have been abused or
neglected by a parent or caregiver as a
result of substance abuse and who are the
subject of court proceedings that oversee
social service efforts to rehabilitate
families or to provide alternate permanent
plans for children.

What is Family Dependency Treatment Court
What is Family Dependency
Treatment Court

precipitated by the substance abuse of a parent or caregiver — by addressing the comprehensive issues of both parents and their children through an integrated, court-based collaboration among service providers who work as a team to achieve timely decisions, coordinated treatment and ancillary services, judicial oversight, and safe and permanent placements.

Considerations for FDTC Implementation
Considerations for FDTC Implementation

Systems Change
Systems Change

–Therapeutic Jurisprudence: “The use of social science to study the extent to which a legal rule or practice promotes the psychological and physical well-being of the people it affects”[1] Therapeutic Jurisprudence further “Suggests mental and physical health aspects of law should be examined …in achieving proposed goals”[2] –Strengths-Based Focus: Identification of the positive characteristics of a child, parent and family in the assessment and development of a case plan and further participation in the family drug court. –Family Broadly Defined: Recognizing the structure of family unit as the child and parent view this system to include the non-traditional family relationships. In addition, an approach to provide services for the entire family and identifying the family as the client. – Comprehensive & Integrated Case Management: Recognition that the child, parent and family are most often involved in various systems; attempting to manage multiple case plans. Family Dependency Treatment Court is an opportunity for agencies to work together , to maximize resources and to create better outcomes for children and families.

FDTC Characteristics
FDTC Characteristics

• Focus on the permanency, safety and
• Focus on the permanency, safety and

welfare of abused and neglected children as well as the needs of the parents.
welfare of abused and neglected children
as well as the needs of the parents.

A Family Dependency Treatment Court addresses the needs of both children and parents, encompassing the entire family as the client.
A Family Dependency Treatment Court addresses the needs of
both children and parents, encompassing the entire family as the b o t h c h i l d r e n
a n d
p a r e n t s ,
e n c o m p a s s i n g
t h e
e n t i r e
f a m i l y
a s
t h e
client.

• Early intervention, assessment and
• Early intervention, assessment and

facilitated access to services for parents and children in a holistic approach to strengthen family function.
facilitated access to services for parents
and children in a holistic approach to
strengthen family function.

FDTC Characteristics
FDTC Characteristics

• Develop comprehensive service plans that address the needs of the entire family system.
• Develop comprehensive service plans
that address the needs of the entire
family system.

Comprehensive assessment of both children and parents to
determine their treatment, developmental, mental and physical

health needs.
health needs.

• Provide enhanced case management
• Provide enhanced case management

services to monitor progress & facilitate access to services.
services to monitor progress & facilitate
access to services.

FDTC Characteristics
FDTC Characteristics

• Regularly scheduled staffings facilitate
• Regularly scheduled staffings facilitate

the exchange of information & coordinate services for the family. Review parent’s progress in treatment and other services and services to children. Update family service plans as needed.
the exchange of information & coordinate
services for the family.
Review parent’s progress in treatment and other services and
services to children. Update family service plans as needed.

• Increased judicial supervision of children
• Increased judicial supervision of children

and families. Review progress toward permanency, ensure provision of services and timely decision making for children and families.
and families.
Review progress toward permanency, ensure provision of services
and timely decision making for children and families.

FDTC Characteristics
FDTC Characteristics

• Individual & systems accountability.
• Individual & systems accountability.

FDTCs hold parents accountable through a graduated system of incentives & sanctions. Judicial monitoring ensures that services necessary to preserve or reunify families are provided.
FDTCs hold parents accountable through a graduated system of
incentives & sanctions. Judicial monitoring ensures that services
necessary to preserve or reunify families are provided.

• Ensuring legal rights, advocacy and
• Ensuring legal rights, advocacy and

confidentiality for parents and children
confidentiality for parents and children

Ensure that advocacy, confidentiality, and due process are maintained by advising the parent and children (and their representatives) of the guidelines for participating in the drug court
Ensure that advocacy, confidentiality, and due process are
maintained by advising the parent and children (and their
representatives) of the guidelines for participating in the drug court

FDTC Characteristics
FDTC Characteristics

• Operate within the Federal mandates of the Adoption and Safe Families Act and Indian Child Welfare Act
• Operate within the Federal mandates of
the Adoption and Safe Families Act and
Indian Child Welfare Act

The ASFA guidelines reduce the deadline for permanency placement hearings for children in foster care from 18 months to 12 months.
The ASFA guidelines reduce the deadline for permanency
placement hearings for children in foster care from 18 months to
12 months.

• Judicial leadership for both the planning
• Judicial leadership for both the planning

and implementation of the court
and implementation of the court

The judge plays a key leadership role in the planning and implementation of an FDTC providing vision and encouraging collaboration.
The judge plays a key leadership role in the planning and
implementation of an FDTC providing vision and encouraging
collaboration.

FDTC Characteristics
FDTC Characteristics

• Commitment to measuring outcomes of the FDTC program and plan for program sustainability
• Commitment to measuring outcomes of
the FDTC program and plan for program
sustainability

Develop a common definition of success and, with this as a base, identify the variables to be studied and establish the procedures to ensure the
Develop a common definition of success and, with this as a base, identify
the variables to be studied and establish the procedures to ensure the

efficient and timely gathering of data.
efficient and timely gathering of data.

• Working as a collaborative, non-
• Working as a collaborative, non-

adversarial team supported by cross- training
adversarial team supported by cross-
training

Communicate to parents with one voice, eliminating the confusion of contradictory messages, strengthening the relationship between the court and the family, and fostering the parent’s motivation to change.
Communicate to parents with one voice, eliminating the confusion of
contradictory messages, strengthening the relationship between the
court and the family, and fostering the parent’s motivation to change.

Transferable Practices
Transferable Practices

• Strategies that can be used in non-FDTCs. • Practices that can be evaluated in

Collaborative Justice in Conventional Courts CCI, 2004
Collaborative Justice in
Conventional Courts CCI, 2004 C o n v e n t i o n a l
C o u r t s
C C I ,
2 0 0 4

Judges identified the following collaborative justice principles and practices as the easiest or most appropriate to transfer:
Judges identified the following collaborative justice
principles and practices as the easiest or most
appropriate to transfer:

• A proactive, problem-solving orientation of the judge • Interaction with the defendant/litigant • Ongoing judicial supervision • Integration of social services • A team-based, non-adversarial approach

What do the parents say?
What do the parents say?

Emotional Support
Emotional Support

• Parents talked about how the drug court team, and in particular the judge and the drug court-dedicated case workers, provide a support system.
• Parents talked about how the drug court team, and in
particular the judge and the drug court-dedicated case
workers, provide a support system.

“The drug court team and the drug court case worker have helped me a lot. My first case worker, that wasn’t the drug court one, didn’t spend much time with me, but my drug court case worker always knew what was going on with me, and helped me get what I needed to get my kids back.”
“The drug court team and the drug court case worker “ T h e

going on with me, and helped me get what I needed to
get my kids back.”

Accountability and Collaboration • Parents also explained how frequent hearings and attendance in drug court provided accountability for their behavior because:
Accountability and
Collaboration
• Parents also explained how frequent hearings and
attendance in drug court provided accountability for
their behavior because:

– “the team knows what’s going on with you and you get immediate support for whatever is going on as soon as you need it.”
– “the team knows what’s going on with you and you get – “ t h e t e a m k n o w s w h a t ’ s g o i n g o n w i t h y o u a n d y o u g e t
immediate support for whatever is going on as soon as
you need it.”

– “it’s helpful going every two weeks because things can these
– “it’s helpful going every two weeks because things can – “ i t ’ s h e l p f u l g o i n g e v e r y t w o w e e k s b e c a u s e t h i n g s c a n
these

time, and in drug court
time, and in drug court

come up during that problems are addressed quickly.”
come up during that
problems are addressed quickly.”

Accountability and Collaboration, cont’d • Frequent court attendance means that the judge and others are well informed about the parents’ cases and able to provide appropriate support for recovery and other issues facing the parent.
Accountability and
Collaboration, cont’d
• Frequent court attendance means that the judge
and others are well informed about the parents’
cases and able to provide appropriate support for
recovery and other issues facing the parent.

“(attending drug court regularly) helps you feel less alone, that someone knows what’s going on in your life and the all the issues that you face, they know how to support you and what you need.”
“(attending drug court regularly) helps you feel less
alone, that someone knows what’s going on in your life
and the all the issues that you face, they know how to
support you and what you need.”
